Key Arguments: The bill will result in more control over free speech by transferring powers to unaccountable administrative agencies.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are imprecise and could suppress political dissent and genuine debate.
The application of misinformation and disinformation is arbitrary and may not apply to governments or media outlets.
There is a lack of provisions for openness, fairness, and recourse for information wrongly fact-checked as false.
The bill could lead to politically motivated censorship and loss of free speech.
Notable Quotes: Our liberal democracy was founded on the principal of free speech and the rule of law.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are imprecise and could be used to capture many instances of political dissent and genuine debate.
The power to declare misinformation and disinformation by unaccountable administrative bodies breeds secrecy and is not a positive step to improve our democracy.
